title: Data Resource Map | Anton Ebsen
description: A guide to the most important economic data sources and how to access them via API.

hero.title: Data Resource Map
hero.text: A curated overview of the data sources I use for macroeconomic analysis, along with technical tips for efficient data collection.

sources.name: Statistics Denmark (DST)
sources.desc: The gold mine of Danish macro data. I frequently use their API for automated retrieval of price indices and national accounts.
sources.tip: Use the 'Statistikbanken' API v1 for time series â€” it's the most stable for Python integration.

sources.name: FRED (Federal Reserve Economic Data)
sources.desc: Essential for US and global economic data. Covers almost everything from interest rates to labor market statistics.
sources.tip: The 'fredapi' Python library is excellent and saves you from writing raw requests.

sources.name: ECB Statistical Data Warehouse (SDW)
sources.desc: The primary source for monetary and financial statistics of the Euro area.
sources.tip: Their SDMX format can be complex; use the Pandas SDMX reader to parse data correctly.

sources.name: OECD Data
sources.desc: Fantastic for international comparisons of well-being, education, and economic indicators.

sources.name: BIS (Bank for International Settlements)
sources.desc: The best source for banking statistics, effective exchange rates, and global liquidity.
